articles.headline: When a Health Insurer Also Wants to Be a Hospice Company
articles.snippet: Humana is teaming up with two investment firms to become the nation’s largest provider of hospice care, dominating a rapidly growing — and controversial — business.
articles.abstract: Humana is teaming up with two investment firms to become the nation’s largest provider of hospice care, dominating a rapidly growing — and controversial — business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Death has always been lucrative enterprise, whether it involves mahogany caskets or teams of estate and tax lawyers. But hospice, the business of caring for those who are nearing death, has become a booming multibillion-dollar industry that is attracting more and more for-profit companies, including one of the nation’s major insurers.

articles.headline: President Trump, Deal Maker? Not So Fast
articles.snippet: After 17 months in office, President Trump has yet to seal many major deals on trade, security, health care, immigration or gun control.
articles.abstract: After 17 months in office, President Trump has yet to seal many major deals on trade, security, health care, immigration or gun control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump likes nothing more than presenting himself as the ultimate deal maker, the master negotiator who can translate his success in business into the worlds of politics, policy and diplomacy. “That’s what I do, is deals,” he said one day last month.

articles.headline: Why Are Parents Bringing Their Children on Treacherous Treks to the U.S. Border?
articles.snippet: President Trump hopes to deter the flow of migrants into the United States, but near the busy border crossing in Arizona, some said that the threat of separation from their children would not deter them.
articles.abstract: President Trump hopes to deter the flow of migrants into the United States, but near the busy border crossing in Arizona, some said that the threat of separation from their children would not deter them.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — When Luis Cruz left behind his wife, four of their children and the house he’d built himself, he’d heard that American officials might split him from his son, the one child he took with him. But earlier this month, the two of them set out from Guatemala anyway.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Jose A. Del Real and Ryan Christopher Jones

articles.headline: South Korea Draws Inspiration From 2002. Ah, but So Does Mexico.
articles.snippet: The two teams meet on Saturday sharing the same role model — the 2002 South Korean squad that made it all the way to the World Cup semifinals based on pure effort.
articles.abstract: The two teams meet on Saturday sharing the same role model — the 2002 South Korean squad that made it all the way to the World Cup semifinals based on pure effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — After months of messages and missed connections, Juan Carlos Osorio finally got an opportunity to sit down and pick the brain of Guus Hiddink in early March.

articles.headline: How Amazon Steers Shoppers to Its Own Products
articles.snippet: The company now has roughly 100 private label brands for sale, but few of those are sold under the Amazon brand.
articles.abstract: The company now has roughly 100 private label brands for sale, but few of those are sold under the Amazon brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started with a simple battery.

articles.headline: As Critics Assail Trump, His Supporters Dig In Deeper
articles.snippet: With the president’s approval rating at 90 percent among Republicans, many supporters say they defend Mr. Trump even with some misgivings because they feel criticism of him is constantly overblown.
articles.abstract: With the president’s approval rating at 90 percent among Republicans, many supporters say they defend Mr. Trump even with some misgivings because they feel criticism of him is constantly overblown.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. — Gina Anders knows the feeling well by now. President Trump says or does something that triggers a spasm of outrage. She doesn’t necessarily agree with how he handled the situation. She gets why people are upset.

articles.headline: Germany’s World Cup Is Saved in the Blink of an Eye (and Flick of a Foot)
articles.snippet: First, Germany was down a goal. Later, it was down a man. But with one swing of Toni Kroos’s right foot, it emerged with a stunning 2-1 victory over Sweden.
articles.abstract: First, Germany was down a goal. Later, it was down a man. But with one swing of Toni Kroos’s right foot, it emerged with a stunning 2-1 victory over Sweden.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The German shots came from the left and the right and, at least once, even off a striker’s chest. They slammed into Swedish legs and Swedish backs and, at least once, right off the goal post.

articles.headline: Is the Border in Crisis? ‘We’re Doing Fine, Quite Frankly,’ a Border City Mayor Says
articles.snippet: Federal data show that the immigration crisis that President Trump has cited the past week to justify the separation of families is actually no crisis at all.
articles.abstract: Federal data show that the immigration crisis that President Trump has cited the past week to justify the separation of families is actually no crisis at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — The mayor of this Texas border city has been dealing with a crisis.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Linda Qiu

articles.headline: Thermostats, Locks and Lights: Digital Tools of Domestic Abuse
articles.snippet: Internet-connected home devices that are marketed as the newest conveniences are also being used to harass, monitor and control.
articles.abstract: Internet-connected home devices that are marketed as the newest conveniences are also being used to harass, monitor and control.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The people who called into the help hotlines and domestic violence shelters said they felt as if they were going crazy.

articles.headline: Six Goals for England and an Open Door Into the Next Round
articles.snippet: Led by Harry Kane’s three goals — two on penalty kicks — England trounced Panama on Sunday. No wonder the Panama coach had a bad feeling about this game.
articles.abstract: Led by Harry Kane’s three goals — two on penalty kicks — England trounced Panama on Sunday. No wonder the Panama coach had a bad feeling about this game.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia — It was Saturday afternoon on the Volga River when Panama’s coach, Hernan Dario Gomez, offered a scary thought — the next day’s World Cup match against England might prove even more lopsided than his team’s 3-0 loss to Belgium in its first game.
articles.byline: By Matthew Futterman and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Is Winning Converts. But Primary Victories Remain Elusive.
articles.snippet: While their goals like a higher minimum wage and “Medicare for All” have gained traction among Democrats, Senator Sanders and his allies have struggled to win elections.
articles.abstract: While their goals like a higher minimum wage and “Medicare for All” have gained traction among Democrats, Senator Sanders and his allies have struggled to win elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — Their rock star had arrived.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Erdogan’s Victory in Turkey Election Expands His Powers
articles.snippet: The vote was the first to be held since Turkey narrowly approved a referendum last year to give the president, once a largely ceremonial role, sweeping executive authority.
articles.abstract: The vote was the first to be held since Turkey narrowly approved a referendum last year to give the president, once a largely ceremonial role, sweeping executive authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkish voters gave President Recep Tayyip Erdogan a decisive victory in national elections on Sunday, lengthening his 15-year grip on power and granting him vastly expanded authority over the legislature and judiciary.

articles.headline: Trump Calls for Depriving Immigrants Who Illegally Cross Border of Due Process Rights
articles.snippet: The president said such immigrants should be sent back immediately without an appearance before a judge.
articles.abstract: The president said such immigrants should be sent back immediately without an appearance before a judge.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump unleashed an aggressive attack Sunday on unauthorized immigrants and the judicial system that handles them, saying that those who cross into the United States illegally should be sent back immediately without due process or an appearance before a judge.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Uber Claims to Have Changed. A London Judge Will Decide.
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing company is appealing a ban in its largest European market. The case is a major test of changes made by its new chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing company is appealing a ban in its largest European market. The case is a major test of changes made by its new chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dara Khosrowshahi’s 10-month tenure as Uber’s chief executive has been marked by a prolonged public relations campaign to apologize for the company’s past misdeeds and portray the once proudly combative start-up as a reformed corporate citizen.

articles.headline: In a High-Stakes Environmental Whodunit, Many Clues Point to China
articles.snippet: Scientists say new production of a banned industrial chemical is damaging the ozone layer. Investigations by The Times and an independent environmental group led to factories in China.
articles.abstract: Scientists say new production of a banned industrial chemical is damaging the ozone layer. Investigations by The Times and an independent environmental group led to factories in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: XINGFU, China — Last month, scientists disclosed a global pollution mystery: a surprise rise in emissions of an outlawed industrial gas that destroys the atmosphere’s protective ozone layer.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: In a Chinese Village, Elderly Farmers Are Now Yogis
articles.snippet: The local Communist Party chief has turned to yoga to bring health and vitality to a fading, remote hamlet. Some tourist money would be welcome, too.
articles.abstract: The local Communist Party chief has turned to yoga to bring health and vitality to a fading, remote hamlet. Some tourist money would be welcome, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: YUGOULIANG, China — As the top Chinese official in this village, Lu Wenzhen had a problem. The young people had all moved away. The elderly farmers left behind were ailing. His aging hamlet needed money. Life. A spark.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen

articles.headline: Politics Ensnare Mohamed Salah and Switzerland at the World Cup
articles.snippet: Salah was said to be considering retiring from Egypt over interactions with a Chechen politician, and two Swiss players caused a firestorm by displaying an Albanian symbol.
articles.abstract: Salah was said to be considering retiring from Egypt over interactions with a Chechen politician, and two Swiss players caused a firestorm by displaying an Albanian symbol.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The World Cup was thrust into the combustible mix of politics and soccer — dangerous ground that world soccer takes great pains to avoid — as a growing number of disciplinary proceedings and a star player’s threatened retirement brought several sensitive international flash points to the tournament’s doorstep this weekend.
articles.byline: By Rory Smith, James Montague and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade War Could Shut Cheesemakers Out of Foreign Markets
articles.snippet: With other countries raising tariffs to American products and signing trade deals without the United States, the American cheesemaker is increasingly standing alone.
articles.abstract: With other countries raising tariffs to American products and signing trade deals without the United States, the American cheesemaker is increasingly standing alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, Wis. — It’s a common observation here that you can’t turn off the cows — not for Christmas, and not for a trade war.

articles.headline: How an Affair Between a Reporter and a Security Aide Has Rattled Washington Media
articles.snippet: The seizure of email records from a Times reporter alarmed First Amendment groups. Her relationship with an intelligence aide set off an ethical debate.
articles.abstract: The seizure of email records from a Times reporter alarmed First Amendment groups. Her relationship with an intelligence aide set off an ethical debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pearl bracelet arrived in May 2014, in the spring of Ali Watkins’s senior year in college, a graduation gift from a man many years her senior. It was the sort of bauble that might imply something more deeply felt than friendship — but then again, might not.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Scott Shane and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: What’s the Yield Curve? ‘A Powerful Signal of Recessions’ Has Wall Street’s Attention
articles.snippet: The bond market’s yield curve is perilously close to predicting a recession — something it has done with surprising accuracy — and it’s become a big topic on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The bond market’s yield curve is perilously close to predicting a recession — something it has done with surprising accuracy — and it’s become a big topic on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can try to play down a trade war with China. You can brush off the impact of rising oil prices on corporate earnings.

articles.headline: Harley-Davidson, Blaming E.U. Tariffs, Will Move Some Production Out of U.S.
articles.snippet: The iconic motorcycle manufacturer said that the move was the “only sustainable option” to maintain its business in Europe, an increasingly vital market.
articles.abstract: The iconic motorcycle manufacturer said that the move was the “only sustainable option” to maintain its business in Europe, an increasingly vital market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump pursues a protectionist trade policy, he has pointed repeatedly to Harley-Davidson, the iconic American motorcycle manufacturer, as a company that will ultimately benefit.

articles.headline: Robots or Job Training: Manufacturers Grapple With How to Improve Their Economic Fortunes
articles.snippet: With unemployment low and wages creeping up, companies have an incentive to become more efficient — an exercise that tends to drive economic progress.
articles.abstract: With unemployment low and wages creeping up, companies have an incentive to become more efficient — an exercise that tends to drive economic progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: HICKSVILLE, Ohio — For Anthony Nighswander, rock-bottom unemployment is both a headache and an opportunity. For businesses and workers, it could be the key to reversing one of the country’s most vexing economic problems: slow productivity growth.
